page.title: 10OLD MILLS IN SOUTHWELL
page.content: Possiby the first mention of{mills in Southwell is in the{Domesday Book in 1086."There are two mills rendering four shillings and a fish pond".These would have belonged to the Lord of the Manor,who was the{Archbishop of York. He would have employed millers and taken the profits.We do not know exactly where these mills were on the {River Greet,}but it is highly likely that the more modern mills are on their sites. Mills are to be found at Maythorne,Station Road and at the bottom of Mill Lane in{Upton.}Before Steam power came,in the eighteenth century water_power was very important (being more reliable than wind) and this is why there are so many mills here .These mills did not suffer from shortage of water in summer because they had ponds.
